description: From Middle English feeste, feste, borrowed from Old French feste, from Late Latin festa, from the plural of Latin festum (“holiday, festival, feast”), from Proto-Italic *fēs-tos, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *dʰéh₁s (“god, godhead, deity”); see also Ancient Greek θεός (theós, “god, goddess”). More at theo-. Doublet of fete, fiesta, and fest.

entries.meaning: A very large meal, often of a ceremonial nature.
examples: We had a feast to celebrate the harvest.
It was a feast for the eyes.

entries.meaning: A festival; a holy day or holiday; a solemn, or more commonly, a joyous, anniversary.

description: From Middle English feesten, festen, from Old French fester, from Medieval Latin festāre, from the noun. See above.

verbs.description: feast (third-person singular simple present feasts, present participle feasting, simple past and past participle feasted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To partake in a feast, or large meal.
examples: I feasted on turkey and dumplings.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hold a feast in honor of (someone).
examples: We feasted them after the victory.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To serve as a feast for; to feed sumptuously.
examples: Or once a week, perhaps, for novelty / Reez'd bacon-soords shall feast his family.
